user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of get_session:
```c
static struct Session *
get_session (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  struct Session *ret;
  const char *cookie;

  cookie = MHD_lookup_connection_value (connection,
                                        MHD_COOKIE_KIND,
                                        COOKIE_NAME);
  if (cookie != NULL)
  {
    /* find existing session */
    ret = sessions;
    while (NULL != ret)
    {
      if (0 == strcmp (cookie, ret->sid))
        break;
      ret = ret->next;
    }
    if (NULL != ret)
    {
      ret->rc++;
      return ret;
    }
  }
  /* create fresh session */
  ret = calloc (1, sizeof (struct Session));
  if (NULL == ret)
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "calloc error: %s\n", strerror (errno));
    return NULL;
  }
  /* not a super-secure way to generate a random session ID,
     but should do for a simple example... */
  snprintf (ret->sid,
            sizeof (ret->sid),
            "%X%X%X%X",
            (unsigned int) rand (),
            (unsigned int) rand (),
            (unsigned int) rand (),
            (unsigned int) rand ());
  ret->rc++;
  ret->start = time (NULL);
  ret->next = sessions;
  sessions = ret;
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function get_session:
struct Session
{
  /**
   * We keep all sessions in a linked list.
   */
  struct Session *next;

  /**
   * Unique ID for this session.
   */
  char sid[33];

  /**
   * Reference counter giving the number of connections
   * currently using this session.
   */
  unsigned int rc;

  /**
   * Time when this session was last active.
   */
  time_t start;

  /**
   * String submitted via form.
   */
  char value_1[64];

  /**
   * Another value submitted via form.
   */
  char value_2[64];

}
...
_MHD_EXTERN const char *
MHD_lookup_connection_value (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                             enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                             const char *key)
{
  const char *value;

  value = NULL;
  (void) MHD_lookup_connection_value_n (connection,
                                        kind,
                                        key,
                                        (NULL == key) ? 0 : strlen (key),
                                        &value,
                                        NULL);
  return value;
}
...
#define COOKIE_NAME "session"
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I found no uses of memcmp in the provided get_session code or the related snippets. The only string comparison is performed with strcmp (if (0 == strcmp (cookie, ret->sid))), which is the correct function to compare null-terminated C strings for this purpose. ret->sid is populated via snprintf, which guarantees a null terminator (so strcmp is appropriate). The helper MHD_lookup_connection_value uses strlen to compute a key length but does not call memcmp. Other operations (calloc, snprintf, rand, time, pointer NULL checks, linked-list traversal) are unrelated to Rule 21.14. Therefore there are no fragments that need investigation for misuse of memcmp on null-terminated strings.
